BE11:20am

Meanwhile, have some Spangel.

BE11:20am

India precipitated the fall in gold prices last Sunday under cover of news the Trump election with local press reports that the government may be considering a complete ban in the shipping of gold into India. We presume this may have been prompted by the move by individuals to convert large denominated Rupee bills, which are being withdrawn, into gold with gold looking set to take over as India’s next black market currency.
Yellen says the Fed could raise rates relatively soon and that Trump has done nothing to change the Fed’s plan for a rate increase
The Fed may also raise rates to assist the Treasury in the issuance of bonds to fund future Trump infrastructure spending
Trump may also lower US corporation taxes as pledged to further repatriate US dollars held in overseas accounts
The flow of funds back into the US could strengthen the dollar further and cause further volatility in the Emerging Markets.
Emerging Markets are fragile and volatile markets at the best of times and a liquidity squeeze in S Korea and other developing nations could well precipitate further crisis.
The question for gold bugs is, how low will gold go as the US dollar strengthens before the next crisis causes the gold price to recover.
Given that currency markets have already priced much of the Trump move into the US dollar and that further strength will damage more exports then it may be that the move in the dollar and the fall in gold prices is largely done
It may also be that the Fed could print new US dollars rather than increasing its borrowings though we seem to be the only people considering this. The inflationary impact of new money printing could be the deciding factor here.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

And some Numis for the sector.

BE11:22am

Trump's stimulus plan has put pressure on gold with a Fed hike in December seen as highly likely... - Market consensus was that a Trump victory would be a significant positive for gold. The rally, such as it was, lasted for only a few hours as the President Elect struck a conciliatory tone and appeared to commit to a significant programme of infrastructure investment and tax cuts. Gold subsequently pulled back through its key short term technical levels and we believe that the metal could remain under some pressure ahead of the December FOMC meeting, where BBG is currently showing a 94% probability of a rate hike. We would note that gold came under pressure ahead of the Fed taper in 2013 and the rate hike in 2015 before then going on to rally by 11% and 16% respectively.

BE11:22am

.... and Renzi could provide a fillip - At present polling suggests that Prime Minister Renzi could lose the constitutional referendum that he has called on December 4th. Should this be the case, he has said that he would stand down, which would result in significant uncertainty in the Eurozone's third largest economy that would probably be a short term positive for gold

11:22 am
BE11:23am

So ..... there we go. That's ..... that. I guess.

11:23 am
PM11:24am

Jon Pierce

PM11:24am

Ive only got the cover sheet, but let me share

PM11:24am

Big rally justified by improving earnings outlook
Brexit fears, it seems, have given way to optimism over higher rate expectations (and to an extent regulatory proposals) with the sector now valued above the level on 23rd June. This is fair. Indeed, we lift 2019E EPS by an average 10% across the sector in-line with our approach of incorporating market rate expectations into our numbers, along with adjustments following Q3 figures.

11:24 am
PM11:24am

More to go on higher rates?
Our numbers now assume five year rates at 1.5% by 2019 and a move to 2% would only add another 6% to EPS. With shares implicitly valuing 2019E EPS on a one-year forward multiple of 10.5 times, we do not see much upside from here. Domestic bank TNAV also includes GBP7bn (6%) of cash-flow hedge reserves that will fall as rates rise. Neither do we think that regulatory risk has gone away. This is not fully captured within target prices with LBG a particular concern for us.

PM11:24am

LBG remains on Underperform - distribution concerns increasing
The market seems happy to take LBG's stated equity tier 1 ratio at face value but our concern is that it now includes 160bps of 'lower quality' capital relating to the reclassification of a bond position and fair value adjustments on HBOS debt. We also believe the ratio could be hit by over 200bps due to IFRS9 and RWA inflation even if proposals are watered down, leaving us cautious on short-term distributions. And so, while the longer-term attractions of LBG's franchise are clear, we think the shares look expensive at 1.1 times current TNAV - which includes a CF hedge reserve (excluding the bond reclassification) equal to 10% of net assets. We remain on Underperform.

PM11:25am

RBS also downgraded to Underperform, Barclays our most preferred UK bank
Given its sensitivity to higher rates, we increase RBS' 2019E EPS by 15% and our 12m target price by 8%. But with the shares trading above this level and with no dividend next year, we move to Underperform. HSBC remains Neutral and Standard Chartered remains Underperform, despite increased target prices reflecting earnings upgrades from higher rates. Our only Outperform rating remains Barclays, where we have increased the 12m target price to 230p.

BE11:35am

•Sports Rights inflation. Seen bifurcation – domestic and EU football expensive. Other rights has seen much more moderate inflation. Sky and others will continue to be focused on what really drives business and where they see value – “will seek to win most important things... but willing to let other things go.” The business has changed – it used be 90% took sport and movies..... that has changed.... Sky has grown other parts of the business. “Sport and football is very important... but gets slightly less important each time.” UK Champions League: “will certainly be at the auction.....not sure yet what rights are going to sell...and how packaged.”

BE11:36am

•Sports viewing – unclear why football viewing down year on year. Believe a seasonal (Euro 2016) factor hasn’t helped and that this was similar to 2012. Darroch acknowledges there is “a bit of other stuff going on..... eg Newcastle/ Villa dropping out of the top-tier”. Darroch believes younger fans demonstrating less commitment to watch whole games given consumption of clips etc.

11:37 am

PM11:38am

Sector watchers not paying attention

PM11:38am

Their loss

11:37 am
BE11:38am

Maybe. But since we're on the theme, here's UBS talking the death of FTA.

BE11:38am

Our monitor shows Netflix and Amazon (UK/Ger) are gaining momentum. We estimate UK SVOD HH penetration is 34% (9m subs), 12% in Germany (5m), 7% in France (2m), 2% in Italy (0.5m) and 2% in Spain (0.3m). SVOD share of video app downloads is now 31% in the UK, 30% in Germany, 22% in France, 21% in Italy but 37% in Spain. Spain has seen the biggest share shift with SVOD share 10% in 2015. Commercial broadcast share of downloads is currently 9-11% (ITV, TF1, M6, RTL, Atres) with Mediaset Spa (20%) and Mediaset Esp. (15%) better positioned. With the pending global launch of Amazon (Grand Tour to be launched in 200 markets in Dec), HBO Go (Spain), Now TV (Spain) we view SVOD penetration will rise putting further pressure on linear relevance.

BE11:38am

Linear viewing is fragmenting. UK linear FTA-TV viewing is down 12% since 2010; with 2016 down 2% (despite sport events). BARB TV player report also shows Broadcasters have not substantially increased non-linear usage which is c5-6mins per day (BBC 52% share, ITV 15%, Sky 22%). In Germany, linear accounted for 77% of 14-49 video consumption in Q216 down from 85% in Q115 while 14+ viewing share has fallen to 88% from 93%. This shift may also explain ProSieben ratings weakness ytd (-160bps, Oct -60bps) given a large exposure to US content (although domestic formats have held up). In Spain, Linear viewing is down c2% but non-linear viewing is less than 2% (vs. 12+% in UK/Germany). In Italy linear viewing is down 2% and is stable in France.

11:41 am

Merrill pushing St James's Place.

BE11:42am

... whose code on the FT system doesn't seem to be SJP, as it is on Reuters. It's up 1.4% to 959.5p whichever way.

11:42 am
BE11:43am

Earnings forecasts are overlook positive news We upgrade St James’s Place to Buy from Neutral, increasing our PO to 1,090p. We think consensus earnings forecasts are lagging good news. Although Brexit is likely to result in ongoing macro uncertainty, we think this is more than reflected in SJP’s stock price. The shares currently sit around their pre-Brexit levels despite FX-positives (USD 16% and EUR 11% moves vs GBP both boost SJP’s assets under management), market growth (FTSE All share +5.5% from pre-Brexit levels) and positive updates at H1 and Q3. We think our cash generation forecasts sit around 5% above consensus.

PM11:43am

(erlkin -- do you know get two tabs at the top of the screen? Markets Live / Comments)

BE11:43am

SJP’s advice model is proving its resilience SJP’s performance post-Brexit hasn’t skipped a beat, with the company reiterating that it has seen no behavioural change from its customers. The trusted relationships of partners with their customers helps protect it against market volatility. The company has stated that it expects to achieve £1bn of gross inflows each month next year, broadly in line with our £11.8bn gross inflow forecast for 2017E.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

New recruitment opportunities; Recent recruits gearing up SJP recently highlighted that its scale opens recruitment opportunities not previously available to it. SJP is now able to nurture new advisers as part of a larger practice, who previously may have been turned away as they were unable to stand on their own. SJP’s advisers also become significantly more productive over time (near doubling between years two & five), yet over 45% of the salesforce has been with SJP less than five years.

BE11:44am

Buy SJP: The place to be; PO 1,090p We see 19% total shareholder return potential to our 1,090p PO. We revise our earnings forecasts down slightly to reflect recent negative market moves and to add some conservatism. However, we remain around 5% above cash generation consensus. SJP trades on 18.2x 2017E underlying cash generation and 16.2x 2018E, an attractive entry point, in our view, for a quality compounder growing AUM, cash EPS and DPS 16-19% CAGR.

BE11:44am

I doubt that's going to excite many of you, but I pass it on anyway.

11:47 am

http://www.evening...ohol_price_ruling/

BE11:47am

The Scotch Whisky Association says it will appeal against the ruling on minimum alcohol pricing in Scotland.

The Court of Session in Edinburgh ruled against the association in October following a legal challenge, saying 'the grounds submitted in the appeal were not well founded'.

They made their final ruling after considering whether the infringement of European trade laws that minimum pricing would bring are justified by the benefits to public health - and if this could be achieved by any other means.

However, the association said that the minimum pricing plan is 'incompatible with EU law'.

It has now applied to appeal the ruling at the UK Supreme Court.

PM11:48am

(erlkin -- you need to click between them)

BE11:52am

Electrocomponents mentioned earlier.

Electrocomponents PLC (ECM:LSE): Last: 429.05, up 59.05 (+15.96%), High: 432.40, Low: 386.20, Volume: 1.47m
11:52 am
PM11:53am

Top of the 250 risers board

BE11:53am

Remarkable turnaound of this thing. 18 months ago or thereabouts it was meant to be dying, as customers moved widget buying online and margins were whittled down to nothing.

BE11:54am

(@erlkin: the one that's open.)

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Management sharpened up buying, cut inventory times, got suppliers onside. Share price now at a 12-month high.

BE11:55am

Here's UBS.

BE11:55am

Exemplary execution continues, see 6-7% EPS upgrades after H1'17
H1'17 PBTA of £55m was itself only £1m ahead of consensus after the pre-close
update, but with momentum continuing across the business (organic growth trending
up, gross margin to improve further in H2, raised cost savings target) we in total raise
EPS estimates by 6-7%. Only 1yr into the 'performance improvement plan', it is safe to
say that performance is significantly improving. We now see EBITA margins of 8.4% in
FY17e, and 9.4% by FY19e, but trading on c17x fwd PE this kind of profitability
recovery is priced in in our view: our Price Target rises to 370p but we stay Neutral.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Growth momentum continues, gross margin improving, cost savings upgraded
Earnings upgrades come from all 3 key areas: 1) We already knew organic growth
accelerated from c1% in Q1 to c3% in Q2, and commentary on October suggests
growth has improved further. We increase our FY17e growth forecasts. 2) Gross
margin +30bps y/y in H1 reflects an underlying +50bps net of an FX headwind; FX will
turn into a tailwind for H2 so we now see an even stronger improvement to come as
underlying efforts are only likely increasing. 3) Management has delivered ahead of
plan on cost savings, and upgraded the total target by FY18e (to £30m, from 'greater than £25m').
EBITA margins were +230bps y/y in H1'16, and we see +200bps for FY17e in total.

BE11:55am

We also note an excellent performance in cashflow: cash conversion of 128%, driven partly by holding back on capex in the near term but also by strong working capital (inventory turns further improved to 2.8x vs. 2.7x at Mar-17). ND/EBITDA is already down to 1.0x and we now see 0.8x by year-end, but there is no mention of change to dividend policy or capital allocation – we expect there to be more of an update by year end. The planning tool is still yet to be rolled out globally, there are new areas of costs to look at etc.: this is evidence of strong early execution but there is much more management wants to do (potential M&A, reinvest in distribution).

BE11:56am

UBSe EPS increase 6-7%, of which half is due to FX. We value Electrocomponents using somewhat of a recovery multiple (17x PE vs. previous mid-cycles 15-16x) to reflect the earnings growth profile, and so our PT increase to 370p with the upgrades.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

And Barclays.

BE11:56am

ELECTROCOMPONENTS (EW, TP289p) – 2Q underlying sales growth +3%, gross margin +0.3pp are in line with guidance in September trading update while adjusted PBT of £55.1m is 2% ahead of the previous £54m guidance. EPS +57% at constant currency (+75% reported basis) and DPS held flat at 5.0p as cover is rebuilt. Leverage of 1.0x vs 1.5x at 31-Mar-16. Outlook reports (i) all regions have seen an improvement in underlying revenue growth in Oct vs 2Q (NB 2Q Group SPD of 3% was an improvement vs 1Q at +0.9%) and (ii) cost saving guidance is increased from “at least £15m” in FY17 and £25m by end of FY18 to new guidance of £18m in FY17 and £30m by FY18. While we are not very surprised by the increased guidance on cost savings as the “at least” comment has preceded guidance on this metric for the last few quarters, this increase is not currently in our forecast and the acceleration in SPD growth is also more positive than we expected; separately we also note the gross margin outlook elsewhere in the statement which talks of a FX transaction tailwind moving forward rather than the headwind it has been for a long period. While management had previously talked of a similar profit outcome in 2H to 1H, we believe that given these positive trends we are now likely to see a stronger 2H than 1H with upside risks to Bloomberg consensus estimates. Based on current consensus forecasts, ECM trades on a Mar-17F PE of 20.9x, falling to 19x in Mar-18F.
